Question

xxx & yyy are two random points selected uniformly between 000 & 111. Using them, create a point uniformly random in a circle of radius 111. (uniform means that the probability density is constant)

Hint

Convert Cartesian coordinates to Polar coordinates. And the area of a circle grows with the square of its radius.

Answer

θ=2πx\theta = 2 \pi xθ=2πx and r=yr = \sqrt{y}r=y​, then take the point as (rcos⁡(θ),rsin⁡(θ))(r \cos(\theta),r \sin(\theta))(rcos(θ),rsin(θ))

Solution

We could generate a random point in the square and reject it if it is not in the circle. However, the question asks to transform the point, not filter it. We need to somehow manipulate the given random point (x,y)(x, y)(x,y)

Initial Misstep

The coordinates of the point in the circle are then given by (rcos⁡(θ),rsin⁡(θ))(r \cos(\theta), r \sin{(\theta)})(rcos(θ),rsin(θ)) where rrr is the radius and θ\thetaθ is the angle. Thus, we can use polar coordinates, xxx can be converted to the angle and yyy can be used as the radius.

  1. Let θ=2πx\theta = 2 \pi xθ=2πx, its value ranged between 000 to 2π2\pi2π

  2. Let r=yr = yr=y, the radius in the polar coordinates, its value is between 0 and 1.

  3. The Polar Coordinate (r,θ)(r, \theta)(r,θ) can be converted to the cartesian coordinate. Thus, (ycos⁡(2πx),ysin⁡(2πx))(y \cos(2 \pi x), y \sin(2\pi x))(ycos(2πx),ysin(2πx)) will generate a random point within the disk of radius 1.

  4. However, to ensure uniform distribution, we can't just take r=yr=yr=y. This is because points near the center of the circle are much more likely to be chosen if we just use a uniform distribution for the radius. Consider a small ring in the circle with radius rrr and thickness drdrdr. The area of this ring (which is a very thin circular strip) is 2π⋅r⋅dr2\pi \cdot r \cdot dr2π⋅r⋅dr. A larger ring has more area and should contain more points. If we take r=yr=yr=y, we end up with the same number of points in each ring. This means that larger rings have a lower density of points. This is not uniform.

Correct Solution

We wish to use (rcos⁡(θ),rsin⁡(θ))(r \cos(\theta), r \sin(\theta))(rcos(θ),rsin(θ)) as the random point, but we need a way to make it uniform.

Uniform distribution means that the probability of finding a point in any part is proportional to the size of that part.

In the case of 1D range [0,1][0, 1][0,1], given yyy is uniform, i.e. P(y1≤y≤y2)=y2−y1P(y_1 \le y \le y_2) = y_2 - y_1P(y1​≤y≤y2​)=y2​−y1​ (where 0≤y1<y2≤10 \le y_1 < y_2 \le 10≤y1​<y2​≤1)

We want the same property for the disk.

Consider an annulus (ring) between radius r1r_1r1​ and r2r_2r2​ (where 0≤r1<r2≤10 \leq r_1 < r_2 \leq 10≤r1​<r2​≤1)

Area of annulus=πr22−πr12\text{Area of annulus} = \pi r_2^2 - \pi r_1^2Area of annulus=πr22​−πr12​

We want the probability to be in proportion to this area, i.e. we want P(r1≤r≤r2)∝(r22−r12)P(r_1 \le r \le r_2 ) \propto (r_2^2 - r_1^2)P(r1​≤r≤r2​)∝(r22​−r12​)

Taking r=yr = yr=y gives P(r1≤y≤r2)=r2−r1P(r_1 \le y \le r_2 ) = r_2 - r_1P(r1​≤y≤r2​)=r2​−r1​, which is not proportional to the area.

But, with a leap of faith, if we take r=yr = \sqrt{y}r=y​, we get

P(r1≤y≤r2)=P(r12≤y≤r12)P(r_1 \le \sqrt{y} \le r_2 ) =P(r_1^2 \le y \le r_1^2)P(r1​≤y​≤r2​)=P(r12​≤y≤r12​)

=r22−r12= r_2^2 - r_1^2=r22​−r12​ (because yyy is uniform in the range [0,1][0, 1][0,1])

Thus, we get the desired property.

Therefore, we can take r=yr = \sqrt{y}r=y​ and θ=2πx\theta = 2 \pi xθ=2πx to get a uniform distribution of points in the disk.
